questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy for gallstones 2.5 years ago. She now presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Investigation reveals a stone in the common bile duct. What is the stone most likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Types

  • Retained common bile duct stones
    • Detected within 2 years of cholecystectomy
  • Recurrent common bile duct stones
    • Detected after 2 years of cholecystectomy (Option D)

Clinical features
  • Charcot’s triad : Pain + Fever + Jaundice
  • Reynauld’s pentad: Mental status changes + Hypotension + Charcot’s triad
  • Biliary colic: A sudden, severe, colicky pain in the right upper quadrant that radiates to the back and shoulder, precipitated by a fatty or heavy meal, and can last for a few hours.
  • Darkening of the urine and lightening of the stools.
  • Steatorrhea, or fatty stools
  • Pruritus (itching), loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, and vomiting

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis
  • Pancreatitis
  • Liver Damage
  • Biliary Stricture
  • Gallstone Ileus

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of?
questions.explanation:
Structures removed: Head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and a portion of the bile duct.

Types:

• Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

• Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

 

Indications

Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localised to the head of the pancreas. 

Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management. 

Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct (distal cholangiocarcinoma), and ampulla of Vater. (Option C)

Procedure Steps

Tumor Assessment: Explore the abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread. 

Resection: Remove the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of the bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection. 

Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes.

Reconstruction

Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect the remaining pancreas to the jejunum. Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to the jejunum. Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum.

Anastomosis Principles

Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing. 

Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy

Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts.

Complications

• Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues. 

• Delayed Gastric Emptying

• Bleeding, wound infection

• Reoperation, increased mortality 

• Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple, the pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of cholecystectomy?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Steatorrhea

Category

Complication

Description/Features

Early (Intraoperative & Immediate Postoperative)

Bile Duct Injury

Accidental damage to the common bile duct (CBD) leads to bile leakage or strictures (More common in laparoscopic cholecystectomy).

Hemorrhage

Bleeding from the cystic artery or liver bed; managed with hemostasis or blood transfusion if severe.

Bowel Injury

Unintended injury to the duodenum or colon, is rare but serious.

Anesthesia-related Complications

Aspiration, respiratory depression, hypotension, and arrhythmias.

Early Postoperative (0–7 Days)

Infection (Wound/Port-Site Abscess)

Fever, erythema, tenderness at the incision site. More common in diabetics or immunocompromised patients.

Bile Leak (Biloma)

Fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and localized fluid collection on imaging. Often from cystic duct stump or accessory bile duct injury.

Subhepatic Collection (Abscess)

Fever, RUQ pain, and tachycardia; requires percutaneous drainage.

Retained Gallstones

Residual gallstones in the bile duct can cause biliary colic or cholangitis postoperatively.

Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) & Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

Due to prolonged immobilization, leading to leg swelling or sudden dyspnea (Prevent with early ambulation, anticoagulation).

Late Postoperative (>7 Days – Months/Years)

Steatorrhea (Fatty Stools)

(Option C)

Most common long-term issue due to continuous bile secretion, leading to fat malabsorption.

Post-Cholecystectomy Syndrome (PCS)

Persistent dyspepsia, bloating, diarrhea, or RUQ pain due to bile reflux or remnant stones.

Biliary Strictures

Chronic narrowing of the CBD, leading to jaundice and cholangitis.

Chronic Diarrhea

Related to altered bile acid metabolism, may require bile acid sequestrants (e.g., cholestyramine).

Increased Risk of Colorectal Cancer (Debatable)

Some studies suggest a mild increase in colon cancer risk due to altered bile acid metabolism, but evidence is weak.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below which shows a ‘colon cut-off sign ’. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Acute pancreatitis

Feature

Description

Definition

Acute inflammation of the pancreas due to premature enzyme activation, leads to autodigestion.

Common Causes (Mnemonic: "I GET SMASHED")

Idiopathic, Gallstones (most common), Ethanol, Trauma, Steroids, Mumps, Autoimmune, Scorpion sting, Hyperlipidemia/hypercalcemia, ERCP, Drugs (thiazides, azathioprine).

Clinical Features

Severe epigastric pain (radiates to back, worsens after food), nausea, vomiting, fever. Severe cases: Cullen’s Sign (periumbilical bruising), Grey Turner’s Sign (flank bruising), Colon Cutoff Sign (gas-filled, distended transverse colon with abrupt cut-off at splenic flexure due to inflammation).(Option B)

Diagnosis (Atlanta Criteria)

≥2 of 3 criteria: (1) Lipase >3x ULN (more specific than amylase), (2) Epigastric pain, (3) Imaging (CT/USG/MRI) evidence. CT scan (best for complications), Ultrasound (detects gallstones).

Severity Classification

Mild: No organ failure, Moderate: <48 hrs organ failure, Severe: >48 hrs organ failure.

Management

IV Fluids (Ringer’s lactate), NPO (Bowel Rest), Pain Control (IV opioids), and Enteral feeding are preferred over TPN. ERCP only if gallstone pancreatitis with cholangitis. No routine antibiotics unless infected necrosis.

Complications

Early (<1 week): SIRS, Shock, ARDS, Renal failure, DIC, Hypocalcemia. Late (>1 week): Necrosis (sterile/infected), Pseudocyst, Abscess, Chronic Pancreatitis, Biliary obstruction.

A 40 year old woman presented with jaundice, fever, and abdominal pain. She is suspected to have cholangitis. Which of the following apart from abdominal pain makes up Reynold pentad? 1. Fever 2. Jaundice 3. Hypotension 4. Altered sensorium 5. Hematemesis 6. Melena
questions.explanation:
Cholangitis

Aetiology

Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species.

Symptoms
  • Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever
  • Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common.
  • Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status
  • Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis.

Lab Findings
  • Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy.

Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis
  • More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections
  • Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is/are correct? 1. TACE(Transarterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions 2. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm 3. The incidence of HCC is increasing 4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC
questions.explanation:
Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. TACE (Transarterial Chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.

True

TACE is used in intermediate-stage (BCLC B) HCC with multiple nodules and preserved liver function (Child-Pugh A/B).

2. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm.

False

Lenvatinib is a systemic therapy for advanced HCC (BCLC C). Small (<3 cm) tumors are treated with resection, RFA, or liver transplant.

3. The incidence of HCC is increasing.

True

The incidence of HCC is rising globally due to increased metabolic syndrome, NAFLD/NASH, obesity, and hepatitis B/C.

4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

True

NAFLD/NASH are leading non-viral causes of HCC. They can cause HCC even in non-cirrhotic livers due to chronic inflammation.

questions.text: What is the most helpful test to identify the underlying cause in a 56-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice, who presents with a distended gall bladder, dilated common bile duct, and enlarged intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound?
questions.explanation:
INVESTIGATIONS - CHOLEDOCHAL CYST

Endoscopic Ultrasound

(Option B ruled out)
  • The first imaging test that is performed.
  • Confirms the presence of the cyst.
  • Reveals anatomical details, including bile duct and pancreatic duct relationship.

Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
  • Non-invasive imaging technique. Provides detailed images of the gallbladder and biliary system.
  • Highly sensitive (>90%) and specific (>99%) for identifying common bile duct stones.
  • Visualizes biliary anatomy and the extent of dilatation.

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):

(Option D ruled out)
  • Invasive procedure with endoscope and contrast material.
  • Diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities (tissue sampling, decompression, treatment of choledocholithiasis).
  • Effective but has a complication rate of up to 10%.

Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography (PTC)
  • Invasive procedure with a needle directly into the liver.
  • Useful for intrahepatic biliary disease or when ERCP is not feasible. (Option C ruled out)
  • Helps delineate surgical anatomy and enables drainage catheter and stent placement.

CT SCAN

Mainly to see the intrahepatic biliary system

Other Tests
  • Hepatobiliary nuclide Scanning
  • Liver Function Tests

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presented with fatigue. Imaging revealed a scleroatrophic gallbladder with impacted stones and a large stone in the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What is the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately take up the patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation:
Choledocholithiasis

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis: Bacterial infection due to obstructed bile flow, leading to fever, chills, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  • Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas due to obstruction at the ampulla of Vater.
  • Liver Damage: Prolonged obstruction can cause biliary cirrhosis and liver failure.
  • Biliary Stricture: Chronic inflammation can lead to the narrowing of the bile ducts.
  • Gallstone Ileus: Large gallstone eroding into the intestine, causing mechanical obstruction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of fever with chills. The MRCP image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)

PSC is characterised by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of extrahepatic and large intrahepatic bile ducts, with dilation of preserved segments.

Demographics
  • It commonly occurs in individuals aged 30-50 years.
  • Has a male predominance of 2:1.

Pathogenesis
  • It suggests an immunologically mediated process supported by circulating autoantibodies and T lymphocytes in the periductal stroma, as well as associations with HLA-B8 and ulcerative colitis.
  • A mix of environmental & genetic factors may trigger bile duct injury.
  • Increased risk of PSC in first-degree relatives indicates a genetic component.
  • Activated T cells from ulcerative colitis mucosa may migrate to the liver, targeting bile duct antigens.
  • Changes in the intestinal microbiome or infections may alter cholangiocytes, causing inflammation.
  • Atypical perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) are

Clinical features
  • Common symptoms include fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice.
  • Nearly 50% of patients are asymptomatic at diagnosis, often identified through elevated serum alkaline phosphatase.
  • Ascending cholangitis, chronic pancreatitis, and chronic cholecystitis may also occur.
  • Fibrosis can progress to cirrhosis over 10-15 years.

Characteristic findings
  • ERCP/MRCP shows the beaded appearance of bile ducts
  • Biopsy,
    • Early features:
      • Periductal "onion skin" fibrosis & inflammation
      • Portal edema & bile ductular proliferation
    • Later stages show progressive fibrosis leading to biliary cirrhosis and obliterative cholangitis, resulting in "vanishing bile duct syndrome"

Associated conditions

Ulcerative colitis, risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma

Complication

Lifetime risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma is about 20%.

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. Upon examination, there was tenderness and enlargement of the liver. Hydatid cyst

Causative agent

Echinococcus granulosus

Commonly Affected Organs
  • Liver (most common site, about 60-70% of cases)
  • Lungs (second most common site)
  • Other organs (rare but possible): Brain, spleen, kidneys, bones, and peritoneum

Clinical Features

Asymptomatic Phase: Common due to slow cyst growth.

Symptomatic Phase:

  • Liver Involvement: Mostly right lobe; Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, obstructive jaundice, portal hypertension.
  • Lung Involvement: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, pneumothorax.

Investigations

Imaging Studies:

  • USG is the first-line imaging modality, particularly for liver involvement.
    • Features: Echinococcal cyst wall shows double echogenic lines separated by a hypoechoic layer (double contour)
  • CT Scan
  • MRI

Serological Tests:

  • ELISA
  • Immunoblotting

Other tests:

  • Casoni Intradermal Test
  • ARC5 Immunoelectrophoresis

questions.text: A patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. A picture of the resected gall bladder is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gall bladder carcinoma

Risk factors
  • Gallstones, (The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population)
  • Porcelain gallbladder,
  • PSC,
  • Abnormal pancreatic-biliary junction

Presentation
  • Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases
  • Symptoms include:
    • Biliary colic
    • Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals)
    • Jaundice (late-stage)
    • Loss of appetite (late-stage)
    • Palpable mass (late-stage)

Lab investigation
  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging & Biopsy
  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

questions.text: What is the term for a stone obstructing the cystic duct, causing dilation of the common hepatic duct, resulting in CBD obstruction and jaundice?
questions.explanation:
Mirizzi’s syndrome

Pathophysiology
  • The gallstone usually impacts from the Hartmann's pouch, leading to compression of the CHD/CBD.
  • Can also occur from the fundus of the gallbladder into the CBD.

Clinical features
  • Fever
  • Abdominal pain
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Upper abdominal tenderness on the right side
  • Possible palpable soft, enlarged liver

Csendes Classification

Type I - Extrinsic compression of the CBD/CHD by a large impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch;

  • IA- the presence of cystic duct
  • IB- is obliterated cystic duct

Type II - The stone has eroded the CBD/CHD less than 1/3rd of the circumference of the CBD/CHD, forming a fistula

Type III - Involving up to 2/3rd of the circumference of CBD/ CHD

Type IV - Cholecystocholedochal fistula (>2/3rd) involving the entire circumference of the CBD/CHD

Type V - Cholecystocholedochal fistula with cholecystoenteric fistula without gallstone ileus (VA) or with

gallstone ileus (VB)

Investigations
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial imaging to assess gallbladder and ducts.
  • CT Scan: Provides detailed imaging of the biliary system.
  • ERCP/ MRCP: Essential for delineating duct anatomy and identifying the site of obstruction.
  • HIDA Scan: Useful for functional assessment of the biliary system.
  • Findings: Dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary system with a block at the common hepatic duct (CHD).

questions.explanation:
Risk Factors For Carcinoma GB

Gallstones:
  • 90% of carcinoma cases are associated with gallstones.
  • The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population.
  • Relative risk based on stone size:
  • Less than 2 cm: Lower risk
  • 2-3 cm: Relative risk of 2.5
  • More than 3 cm (Option D): Relative risk of 10 or more

Other Conditions:
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction (20%)
  • Gallbladder polyps (more than 1 cm in size, more than 3 in number, or adenomatous polyps)
  • Porcelain gallbladder (Option A): 25% risk of malignant transformation, with 90% being inoperable tumours
  • Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (Option B)

Infections and Inflammatory Conditions:
  • Chronic typhoid carriers
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus infections

Other factors:
  • Polypoid lesions (GB polyp)
  • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis
  • Nitrosamines
  • Carcinogens
